name: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA)
description: California state law enhancing privacy rights and consumer protection for California residents

applicabilityThresholds.dataVolume: Buy, sell, or share personal information of 100,000+ CA residents or households
applicabilityThresholds.revenueFromSales: Derive 50%+ of annual revenue from selling or sharing CA residents' personal information

consumerRights: Right to Know (categories and specific pieces)
Right to Limit Use of Sensitive Personal Information
mandatoryElements: Categories of third parties receiving data
Notice of right to opt-out of sales/sharing
Notice of right to limit sensitive personal information use
sensitivePersonalInformation: Social security, driver's license, state ID, or passport number
Account log-in, financial account, debit card, or credit card number with access code
Racial or ethnic origin, religious or philosophical beliefs, or union membership
Contents of mail, email, and text messages (unless business is intended recipient)
Sex life or sexual orientation information

specialConsiderations.minors: Opt-in consent required for sale/sharing of data for consumers under 16
specialConsiderations.requests: Consumers may submit requests up to twice per year, free of charge
specialConsiderations.verification: Reasonable verification methods required to confirm consumer identity
specialConsiderations.penalties: Up to $7,988 per intentional violation (as of 2025)
specialConsiderations.cpraEnhancements: California Privacy Rights Act (CPRA) amendments effective January 1, 2023
specialConsiderations.enforcement: California Privacy Protection Agency (CPPA) enforces violations
